keywords: Beach, seining, fish sampling, habitat selection, net design, efficiency

abstract:
The text describes a fishing method called beach and pole seining. This technique is used to capture fish in various types of water habitats such as rivers, lakes, reservoirs, and marine environments. Seining is most effective in shallow waters with few obstructions where fish are abundant, but it can also be used to catch more mobile species like salmon.

Seining allows for the sampling of large areas quickly while minimizing stress or harm to the fish as long as the net stays submerged and fish are not too crowded. The cost of equipment, boats, and personnel varies depending on the scale of the project.

The method can be used in different habitat types, but sites with uneven bottoms, debris, large rocks, or dense vegetation may not be suitable due to net snagging and reduced fish retention. Current velocity and depth influence site selection and net design.

Factors affecting selectivity and capture efficiency include habitat, water conditions, fish species and behavior, time of year and day, net size and design, and method used. Considering these factors before and during sampling will help determine if seining is a suitable technique to meet objectives and improve data analysis.

Circle set beach seining can be used for analyzing fish per unit area or volume. By setting the seine in a nearly perfect circle and measuring the diameter and maximum/minimum depths at opposing points, the area and volume can be calculated using provided equations. However, efficiency must also be calibrated to ensure accurate results.

In summary, beach and pole seining is an efficient method for capturing fish across various habitats. It's particularly effective in shallow waters with high fish concentrations, but can also capture mobile species like salmon. By considering factors such as habitat, water conditions, fish behavior, time of year and day, net design, and method, researchers can decide when seining is suitable for their objectives and improve data analysis. Circle set beach seining specifically allows for fish per unit area or volume analysis through calculating the seine's circumference, diameter, and depth measurements.

description:
Title: A Technical Analysis of Beach Seining as an Efficient Fisheries Sampling Method

Beach and pole seining is a fishing technique used to efficiently capture fish in various habitats, including rivers, estuaries, nearshore lakes, reservoirs, and marine environments (Pierce et al. 1990). The method is most effective in relatively shallow waters with few obstructions, where fish concentrations are high, and for species that are less likely to outmaneuver the net (Refer to Figure 1 for a visual representation of seining).

Fig. 1: Seining process in action

The efficiency of seining depends on several factors. These include habitat characteristics, water properties, fish behavior, time of year and day, net design, and methodology. For instance, habitats with irregular bottom topography, significant debris or larger rocks, or dense stands of aquatic vegetation may not be suitable for seining due to net snagging or difficulty in lifting the net (Pierce et al., 1990). Current velocity and water depth influence site selection and choice of net design.

Seines come in various sizes and designs, with circular set beach seining being a commonly used method for fish/set, fish/area, and fish/volume analysis (see Figure 2). To calculate the area and volume using this method, it is essential to set the seine in a nearly perfect circle. Measuring the diameter at opposing points of the perimeter and the maximum and minimum depths at these points provides the necessary data for computation (Equations in Box 1).

Fig. 2: Diagram of circular set beach seining

Calibration studies are crucial to ensure efficiency, as variations in net size, fish behavior, and environmental conditions can impact selectivity and capture rates significantly. To minimize stress and harm to captured fish, the bunt (bottom) of the seine should remain submerged, while excessively crowded fish should be quickly moved to a holding container (Pierce et al., 1990).

Costs associated with beach seining vary depending on factors such as scope and frequency. These expenses include gear costs (e.g., netting material), boats (optional), and personnel labor (Pierce et al., 1990). A more detailed analysis of the cost-effectiveness of beach seining requires further research.

Understanding how each factor influences selectivity, capture efficiency, and overall effectiveness is crucial for designing a study that leverages the strengths of this fisheries sampling technique while minimizing its limitations. Careful planning before and during sampling will help researchers make informed decisions on when to use seining to meet their objectives.
